Right, one of the big questions here,

one of the big questions

when Trump makes a decision
is can he legally do that.
And, because we're talking about it now,
you can probably guess that the answer
is not a simple answer.

Trump could invoke the
Insurrection Act of 1807

which gives the president the
power to deploy the military

for domestic law enforcement
under certain circumstances.
This however is very rare.
The last time is was used was in 1992

during the Rodney King
riots in California.
But notably there,

that was at the request
of the states' governor.

Trump also does have significant
power over what he can do

within the borders of
the district of Columbia

but the ways in which the
president can use troops
domestically are more limited
without the approval of a state.

And that's because the
president could only deploy

Now notably here, the
Insurrection Act does say

that the president can send
the military to a state

without the approval of the
states' governor or legislature,
but they can only enforce federal laws.

And even then, if Trump

he would first have to issue

And there are historic examples

And currently no states have publicly said
